comments.body: Can you add some docs for it?

Please don't put this in api/types.go

My suggestion is to just use raw type `map[string]string`
Sorry. I think it's fine here because it's scheduler/api/.
Please add a comment to each field of this struct.

Completely unrelated, but if we moved things like this to their own file we could have the docs be automatically generated/updated...  https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/docs/devel/how-to-doc.md#how-to-include-an-example

Not sure if we want to introduce that pattern into the project, as it hides the `type` away from the code author...   I wonder how hard it would be to get the munger to handle it in place...

No need to address this comment, just thinking outloud...
I realize that the previous iteration of these didn't have Godoc either but they really should as they are exported.
Is there a human-friendly description of the types in this file? The names alone aren't quite clear enough for me to follow.

Does the predicate/priority type description in the document address this?
https://github.com/openshift/openshift-docs/blob/master/using_openshift/scheduler.adoc
Yes, would love to see a version of that doc in our repo.

One nit there: https://github.com/openshift/openshift-docs/blob/master/using_openshift/scheduler.adoc#step-2-prioritize-the-filtered-list-of-nodes

says the range is 0-10, but really the range should be -10 through 10 excluding 0. (since you allow negative weights)

The range is for the score that the priority functions give to each minion and that is correctly stated as 0-10. The weight is allowed to be specified as a negative or positive non-zero integer. The resultant score (after multiplying with the weight) could be any positive/negative integer. 

Actually, the priority functions themselves have no clue about the weight since that is managed outside the priority function (within the PriorityConfig or the PriorityConfigFactory). It is the generic scheduler that multiplies the minion scores with the weight for the given priority function.
Yeah, but just for consistency, if you can make negative preferences with a weight, you should also be able to have them directly. IMO.
